h3. Summary

The administration UI for Smart Mirrors does not work in certain cases when cookies (especially third party cookies) are blocked.
h3. Environment
 * Safari 9
 * Chrome
 * Firefox

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # (Prerequisite) Have a Bitbucket Server Smart Mirror running and configured
 # Go to {{<base_url>/plugins/servlet/admin/mirrors}}
 # Attempt to add a project (or any other protected action)

h3. Expected Results

The selected project is added and synchronized with the mirror.
h3. Actual Results

An error message is shown, prompting to refresh the page and try again.
 !error.png|thumbnail!
h3. Notes

The mirror's administration UI is served via an iFrame. It is possible to configure a browser not so send cookies for the iFrame. This is normally related to third-party cookie settings in browsers. This will break the admin UI as it expects a cookie to be sent to indicate that the user is logged in.

Safari, by default, and in contrast to other browsers, will not accept cookies from a domain in an iFrame (unless cookies already exist for that domain). 
h3. Workaround

*Safari*
 # Set Safari to always allow cookies
 ## Open Safari
 ## Open Preferences
 ## Click on the 'Privacy' tab
 ## Select 'Always allow' for 'Cookies and website data'
 ## Refresh the mirror administration page
 ## For more information see [this Apple KB Article|https://support.apple.com/kb/PH21411?locale=en_US]
 # Use another browser to administer the mirror

*Firefox*

Ensure that the following setting in Preferences > Privacy > History is not enabled. See the [firefox documentation|https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/enable-and-disable-cookies-website-preferences] for details.
 !firefox-third-party-cookies.png|thumbnail!

*Chrome*

Ensure that the following setting in Preferences > Show Advanced Settings > Content Settings is not enabled. See the [chrome documentation|https://support.google.com/chrome/answer/95647] for details.
 !chrome-third-party-cookies.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Bitbucket Server mirror administration does not work when third party cookies are disabled

fields.description:
As part of comment drift processing, {{git diff}} is run to identify comments which need to be moved up or down, or removed entirely because they were made on lines which have been changed.

These {{git diff}} processes use the standard timeouts, meaning they get one minute of "idle" time (where they produce no output), and 2 minutes of _total execution time_.After two minutes, even if the processes are still running, they're canceled. For extremely large pull requests, whether modifying a large number of files, or making changes in large files, or both, two minutes may not be enough.

Comment drift should apply a separate timeout for its processes, to allow it to be configured without having to raise the global idle and execution timeouts for all processes. Additionally, there may be ways in which the {{git diff}} command being run could be optimized. As part of addressing this issue, such potential optimizations should be investigated. Comment drift is a frequently-performed operation, so any optimizations here could greatly benefit pull request-heavy instances.
fields.summary: Comment drift processing can timeout for extremely large pull requests

h3. Summary

Under some rare conditions (for example, unusual activity on the {{/plugins/servlet/oauth/request-token}} endpoint), threads may become deadlocked in database queries involving the {{plugin_setting}} table.  This deadlock ties up connections to the database and increases the likelihood that further threads will also become deadlocked.  In extreme cases, threads may no longer be able to obtain connections from the DB connection pool, and the instance may require restarting. 

h3. Symptoms

If affected, the number of open connections to the database does not return to 0 even when idle, but increases monotonically.  It is possible to monitor the number of open database connections in Stash or Bitbucket Server directly using the following JMX beans:

 * Stash 3.8 to 3.11, {{com.jolbox.bonecp.BoneCP.TotalLeased}} as described in https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH0311/Enabling+JMX+counters+for+performance+monitoring
 * Bitbucket Server 4.0 or higher, {{com.zaxxer.hikari.Pool (bitbucket).ActiveConnections}} as described in https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/enabling-jmx-counters-for-performance-monitoring-776640189.html

If affected, a Stash instance may remain up for a while (days or longer) with no adverse effects except for a mildly elevated number of open database connections.  But once deadlocked, the risk of further threads becoming deadlocked on the same resource increases.  If very many threads become deadlocked, the DB connection pool (with 80 connections by default) may run out and the instance will require restarting.

An analysis of the open transactions on the database (for example, with {{select \* from pg_stat_activity order by xact_start;}} in PostgreSQL) while Stash is affected by this issue will show a number of (possibly very old) connections stuck in queries on the {{plugin_setting}} table, for example:

{noformat}
delete from plugin_setting where id=$1
update plugin_setting set key_name=$1, namespace=$2, key_value=$3 where id=$4
{noformat}

Thread dumps of Stash taken while affected by this issue may also contain many threads blocked with {{com.atlassian.stash.internal.plugin.CachingPluginSettings}} classes mentioned in the stack traces.

h3. Workarounds

1. Avoid integrations which make frequent requests on the {{/plugins/servlet/oauth/request-token}} endpoint.  Atlassian products generally only make requests to this endpoint once every few hours, but third party integrations may make such requests more frequently.  You can check your {{atlassian-stash-access-\*.log}} or {{atlassian-bitbucket-access-\*.log}} files to find such activity. 
2. Avoid plugins that perform {{PluginSettings}} API calls in large transactions.  Note that the bundled Atlassian OAuth Plugin can perform very many {{PluginSettings}} API calls under some conditions, see the related issue https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/OAUTH-321.
3. Stash 3.11.6 contains a mitigation that makes this deadlock exceedingly unlikely to occur. (See BSERV-8522)
4. If affected, forcibly terminating very old transactions stuck on queries on the {{plugin_setting}} table at the database level may clear the deadlock without requiring Stash or Bitbucket Server to be restarted. 

h3. Solution

Bitbucket Server 4.1.0 contains a solution that prevents the deadlock from occurring.
fields.summary: Deadlock between CachingPluginSettings cache and Hibernate

*As a developer*
I would like to approve portions of a pull request

*so that I*
can ignore changes I've already seen/approved on future updates to the pull request.

Currently: Sometimes I'll be reviewing a large pull request that spans many files. I will add comments. The author will then reply to the comments make changes and push them up to BitBucket. Then I'll review and make more comments. Rinse/repeat. Each time I re-review, I have to go through all the changes I've already seen in the off-chance that I've missed something.

Proposal: I would love to mark individual changes and/or entire files as having been approved/read. If further updates to the pull request don't affect those changes/files, then rather than seeing the red/green difference, perhaps they show up as some other color (grey?). This would allow me to easily focus on the new changes to the pull request since I last viewed it.

I posted this wish to my team HipChat and it was met with a resounding yes! I have a feeling this would be a *very* popular feature.

fields.description:
When the AMI was originally designed, 10 GBytes was thought to be "big enough" for the root volume because

a. we didn't want to give customers unnecessary expense for what might initially be entry-level or evaluation sized instances,
b. Amazon Linux itself (from which the Bitbucket AMI descends) only had a root volume size of 8 GBytes, and
c. most EC2 instances available at the time had at least 32 GBytes of Instance Store (onboard SSD) which the AMI configures for use as {{$BITBUCKET_HOME/caches}} and {{$BITBUCKET_HOME/tmp}}. 

Now Amazon has released the "m4" family of instances which have no Instance Store, so {{caches}} and {{tmp}} end up on the root volume.  In stress tests we are finding that 10 GBytes is very easy to fill up with logs and SCM cache files, leading to a poor initial experience. 

We should increase the root volume size from 10 GBytes to something a bit more realistic, like 50 GBytes.
fields.summary: Bitbucket AMI: Increase size of root volume from 10G to 50G

fields.description:
h4. Problem
Currently administrators can tune their Bitbucket Server installations for performance by adjusting the {{throttle.resource.scm-hosting}} [application property|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-config-properties-776640155.html]. However, this setting will apply universally to all operations, regardless of their resource usage and run time.

h4. Proposed solution
There are multiple ways to tackle this and also multiple aspects to consider. 

h5. Scale automatically
Ideally Bitbucket could dynamically scale, say one could set the cap for CPU and memory utilization percentage and depending on the server load it would queue incoming requests instead of trying to serve them, once those pre-defined limits are reached - scaling down the concurrent operations on-the-fly.

h5. Adjust concurrency per-operation-type
The current setting only allows tuning the concurrency for all operations, although there are less expensive operations that could be executed, without seriously impacting performance. The idea is to have a per-operation setting for concurrency and define number of concurrent clones, pushes, etc separately.

h5. Make concurrency adjustable runtime
Now you need to adjust such concurrency settings in {{bitbucket.properties}} then restart the instance for the setting to take effect. This is something that would be best to tune runtime through the administration UI.
fields.summary: Improve concurrency scaling
